channel.title: The New York Times Trends
channel.description: 用中文浏览纽约时报热门报道

item.title: The New York Times analyzed court documents, texts and hundreds of videos to reveal how the Proud Boys instigated critical breaches of the Capitol on Jan. 6. https://t.co/e6ywYf6wMs https://t.co/gZ85j1Ywjs

Representative Bennie Thompson, chairman of the Jan. 6 committee, has spent his career fighting to protect the right to vote. He said the committee’s work was among the most important he had engaged in as a politician. https://t.co/TDmXSU4tui

The father of a teenage girl filed a lawsuit against three police officers in Loveland, Colorado, who arrested her in 2020, saying they used excessive force when they slammed the 14-year-old onto concrete, fired a Taser at him and choked the family’s dog. https://t.co/DclcSEMa3R
Breaking News: Prime Minister Boris Johnson paid a second surprise visit to Kyiv with a new offer of training for the Ukrainian military. https://t.co/K2ZOmupStA

FIFA selected 16 host cities for the 2026 World Cup, which will sprawl across the U.S., Canada and Mexico.
See the full list here. https://t.co/37u7rWtvqy

President Vladimir Putin’s appearance at the St. Petersburg International Economic Forum was delayed by “large-scale” cyberattacks on the conference’s computer systems, the Kremlin said. https://t.co/w61L2C0GOL

Donald Trump condemned Mike Pence even as he knew rioters were violently storming the Capitol while his vice president was inside, the House committee investigating Jan. 6 said.
Pence fled for his life, and at one point was just 40 feet away from the mob. https://t.co/H4oxgU3DpZ
Breaking News: Vince McMahon, the WWE executive, has stepped down while the company investigates allegations of misconduct against him. https://t.co/vDxY2k9cXL

SpaceX fired employees who helped write and distribute an open letter criticizing Elon Musk's public behavior and tweeting, said three employees with knowledge of the situation. https://t.co/IPVl2XIuBr

BTS has become not only a cultural sensation, but also a powerful stakeholder in South Korea's economy.
In just one day after the group announced it would be taking a break to focus on solo projects, the band's label, HYBE, saw its stock price plunge 28%. https://t.co/WAyHLCue8C https://t.co/yTTzDa6yh9

Revlon filed for bankruptcy this week. The cosmetics brand has struggled to attract younger shoppers who are choosing celebrity makeup lines like those by Kylie Jenner and Rihanna. https://t.co/HNp9DMAoIl

Mike Pence made it clear he's considering a 2024 presidential bid by traveling to early states and endorsing candidates opposed by Donald Trump. Pence told The New York Times he's heard gratitude from voters for refusing to bend to pressure. https://t.co/RE0GGvWphX
Breaking News: The European Commission recommended Ukraine for EU candidacy, the first formal step in a process that normally takes more than a decade. https://t.co/8hty3nKPUV

Golden State won the NBA championship after defeating the Boston Celtics, 103-90, on Thursday.
Stephen Curry was named the most valuable player of the finals. “Without him, none of this happens,” Golden State Coach Steve Kerr said. https://t.co/t6aAeWqiET https://t.co/Z6YmIU4rCx

For many of Johnny Depp’s fans, “the actor’s physical appeal offered an external manifestation of inner worth,” Rhonda Garelick writes. While Amber Heard’s beauty “was frequently held against her, offered as proof of her capacity to deceive.” https://t.co/OvWdEzlCVa

SpaceX fired employees who helped write and distribute an open letter criticizing Elon Musk's public behavior and tweeting, said three employees with knowledge of the situation. https://t.co/WWxZRuXEzj
Golden State won its fourth title in eight seasons, beating the Boston Celtics in Game 6 of the NBA finals. https://t.co/JDxwbTu3UR

A lawsuit filed last week by a South Florida synagogue challenges new legislation in the state banning most abortions after 15 weeks, saying it violates the State Constitution’s right to privacy and freedom of religion. https://t.co/KgwMUfVPPj

Students in Hong Kong will soon be given textbooks that say Hong Kong was never a British colony.
The books are part of China’s effort to instill a historical narrative in a city where a pro-democracy movement was crushed. https://t.co/Ubm7X1xmk3

Representative Liz Cheney, the vice chairwoman of the House Jan 6. committee, started the panel's third public hearing by describing Donald Trump's efforts to stay in office as "illegal and unconstitutional." https://t.co/lPfIOvIANn
Breaking News: A lawyer advising Donald Trump on his plan to overturn the election acknowledged to him that it was illegal, an aide to Mike Pence testified. https://t.co/Dey4KnqTIu

John Eastman, the lawyer who insisted that Mike Pence had the power to unilaterally reject the Electoral College results before they were certified, suggested days after the Capitol riot that he should be on the list for a presidential pardon. https://t.co/bcXI68HxGP https://t.co/AEjVkRjgBx

Ghislaine Maxwell, pleading for mercy two weeks before she is to be sentenced in her sex-trafficking case, had her lawyers send a memo to the judge blaming her actions on a "difficult, traumatic childhood" and on her relationship with Jeffrey Epstein. https://t.co/SOjR0H8qKg

President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine appeared in the form of a hologram before four European digital festivals on Thursday, asking the region’s innovators to help rebuild his country. “We live in a time of super opportunities,” he said. https://t.co/9TNJMaZ7me

Federico Carboni on Thursday became the first person in Italy to die by legal assisted suicide. Paralyzed 12 years ago in a traffic accident, he faced a series of legal, bureaucratic and financial hurdles in his pursuit of death. https://t.co/doRy32tnkQ
Breaking News: John Eastman, who advised Donald Trump on overturning the 2020 election, sought a pardon from Rudy Giuliani after the Capitol riot, the Jan. 6 panel said. https://t.co/M2IYG6XGMJ

If Mike Pence obeyed Donald Trump’s orders not to certify the Electoral College votes, it would have put the U.S. into “a revolution within a constitutional crisis,” J. Michael Luttig, a retired judge said to the vice president's advisor ahead of Jan. 6. https://t.co/vFumpDySvJ https://t.co/tHLx2tmx3U

SpaceX employees wrote an open letter to executives about Elon Musk’s behavior on Twitter, calling it “a frequent source of distraction and embarrassment.” The letter follows recently publicized allegations of sexual misconduct against Musk. https://t.co/kAPvwUQGD9

The House Jan. 6 committee released footage of a man who toured the Capitol complex with a Republican lawmaker the day before the attack. The man later marched on the building while making threats against Speaker Nancy Pelosi and other Democrats. https://t.co/1lfo4rHenR https://t.co/lm9uM05hQc

Judge J. Michael Luttig, who consulted with an adviser to Mike Pence ahead of Jan. 6, testified that if Pence obeyed Donald Trump's "orders" about Electoral College votes, it would have "plunged" America into "a revolution within a constitutional crisis." https://t.co/Gpx6mzAY4Z

A wooden gallows, carrying a chilling threat against officials in the Capitol building, remains one of the most disturbing images from the Jan. 6 attack, though who built it remains a mystery. It may be mentioned again in Thursday’s hearing. https://t.co/riA6bjEvwv https://t.co/yhXYMm7TrR

Herschel Walker, the Republican nominee for Senate in Georgia who has been a frequent critic of absentee fathers, has now acknowledged having fathered three additional children he had not previously mentioned publicly. https://t.co/T8R3g7w25q

A new Beyoncé album is coming.
The new project, called “Renaissance,” apparently with the subtitle “Act I,” will be released on July 29, according to the the singer’s social media accounts. https://t.co/ljzQdoR9o5

The leaders of Italy, Germany, France and Romania met with President Volodomyr Zelensky of Ukraine in Kyiv in a show of support. The European leaders also toured Irpin, where Russian soldiers are accused of committing atrocities.
Follow our updates. https://t.co/dVzH4YgYSn https://t.co/OkVS0vpekU

The 41-year-old who leads the crypto exchange Kraken has challenged the use of preferred pronouns, debated who can use racial slurs and called women in the U.S. “brainwashed" — igniting a culture war among his more than 3,000 workers. https://t.co/u8M588awki

Students in Hong Kong will soon be given textbooks that say Hong Kong was never a British colony.
The books are part of China’s effort to instill a historical narrative in a city where a pro-democracy movement was crushed. https://t.co/m7Qolkigcg
Breaking News: A lawyer advising Donald Trump claimed to know about a “heated fight” among Supreme Court justices over whether to hear 2020 election arguments. https://t.co/4XCCSKmaDc

The leaders of France, Germany and Italy traveled to Ukraine on Thursday and will meet with President Volodymyr Zelensky for the first time since Russia’s invasion began. The visit comes as questions mount over European support for Ukraine. https://t.co/G9TerIdNTR https://t.co/QPyfy80jUF

“Lightyear,” an animated Disney film, is facing bans or restrictions in parts of Southeast Asia and the Middle East over a scene that shows a kiss between two women.
The United Arab Emirates has banned the film, and Malaysia has asked Disney to cut scenes.https://t.co/JiTzQKE2UF

Scientists are raising the alarm that in the coming years destruction related to climate change will reach nearly all 423 national parks in the U.S., which are particularly vulnerable to rising temperatures. https://t.co/10JvAYTzyw

A fisherman has confessed that he helped kill a British journalist and a Brazilian expert on Indigenous peoples and then went with the authorities to look for their bodies, according to Brazilian federal police. The men were missing since June 5. https://t.co/xljSUWz0al

Breaking News: Over the course of 10 months, nearly 400 car crashes in the U.S. involved advanced driver-assistance technologies, data from the country's top auto-safety regulator revealed. https://t.co/YVJr0zqNQe

President Biden signed an executive order on Wednesday aimed at protecting LGBTQ people from a cascade of legislation in conservative states that increasingly targets the rights of gays, lesbians, transgender youth and others. https://t.co/dtvh3S3nop

A Delaware man who flew a Confederate battle flag inside the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, was convicted with his son on Wednesday by a federal judge of the top count in their indictment: obstructing the certification of the 2020 presidential vote. https://t.co/WdQnZ4lAoV

Breaking News: FDA advisers recommended that the Moderna and Pfizer coronavirus vaccines be authorized for children as young as 6 months old. Regulators could authorize both vaccines for use on an emergency basis later this week. https://t.co/iShu6oifTt

Internet Explorer was officially retired Wednesday. The web browser, introduced by Microsoft in 1995, was loved and loathed by a generation. "Even though I don’t use it anymore, I'm still going to miss the idea of it," said one user. https://t.co/tmJG7DQx1A
Confirmed: Dogs are still great. https://t.co/Bk9HnyLR9Q https://t.co/zpNmiPOtOD

A man who toured the Capitol with Rep. Barry Loudermilk the day before the Jan. 6 attack later marched on the building, the Jan. 6 committee said. The complex was closed to the public at the time and the group entered three different office buildings. https://t.co/4KdVV5oWgz

Over 10,000 visitors have evacuated Yellowstone after heavy rains and severe flooding slammed the national park, destroying roads and threatening homes. "I’ve heard this is a thousand-year event," said the superintendent of the park. https://t.co/6QG0Ujeufh https://t.co/PWHWGbwCbF
Breaking News: President Biden promised another $1 billion in military aid to Ukraine, including more long-range weapons. https://t.co/2dcAMWMLeH
